{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3413689,"name":"Sarah Withee","username":"geekygirlsarah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geekygirlsarah/{size}/172508_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-06T17:05:37.910Z","cooked":"

At WVROX this past weekend, I was put into a CSA role last minute. I hadn’t ever done it before, so I didn’t totally know what I would be in for, both for the role, but also at a 26 hour event and the mistakes that happen late at night.

About 10 pm, one team was complaining of auto and teleop both not working right, including weird drift issues. How they described it didn’t make sense to me, so I went to their pit and we talked it over more. Something still seemed off and I couldn’t quite figure it out. I asked them to tip the robot on the side and start driving it and maybe we could see what the motors were doing. As they did that, I noticed a roll of electrical tape next to one of their swerve wheels. “Is that supposed to be there?” I asked. “Oh crap! How’d that get there?” replied a student. “The tape looks like it got shredded by the gears” replied another. Turns out their robot worked perfectly fine when a wheel wasn’t getting caught next to a roll of electrical tape.

I’d love to know what’s everyone’s silliest technical issue you ran into? Could be mechanical, electrical, programming, whatever. FRC or FTC. The sillier the better.

we still don’t know how it got there, I’m pretty sure it wasn’t even ours

Having path planner paths not updating, calling in a CSA, who tells you that it is because of a hyphen in the file name, remove those, only to realize after you messed up during a playoffs match that it was a spelling mistake in the code pointing it to the incorrectly spelled auto file, which hasn’t updated or been removed from the deploy directory (looking forward to next seasons changes).

Anyone have a similar experience?

Right now 7900 is experiencing a bug where two different programming laptops with the exact same code cause the robot to behave differently.

We can use the same driver station and it behaves different depending on which deployed it

Technologyman00:

Right now 7900 is experiencing a bug where two different programming laptops with the exact same code cause the robot to behave differently

I’ll venture a guess that you have different versions of a vendor library on the two different programming laptops

Spent an entire competition troubleshooting pathplanner not following paths until I realize the robot starting pose was rotated in a 180 and it was driving into the speaker every time we tried it during a match.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":56,"updated_at":"2024-08-07T04:32:09.980Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":547,"readers_count":546,"score":149.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469589,"topic_slug":"whats-your-silliest-technical-issue","display_username":"Ryan Hubbs","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53872,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2152 | FIRST in FL | MoSim"},"post_url":"/t/whats-your-silliest-technical-issue/469589/8","custom_user_title":"2152 | FIRST in FL | MoSim","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":7},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413893,"name":"Alex","username":"ajs2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ajs2/{size}/200927_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-07T06:58:33.317Z","cooked":"

We’ve had two particularly silly mistakes - these happened at the same regional, within a few hours of each other:

  1. Our arm’s chain fell off the sprocket. When we picked the robot up onto the cart, we put it the wrong way (arm facing the space for the operator console). The arm falls down on the way to the pit and breaks our laptop screen: iCloud Photos - Apple iCloud Thankfully, we had a donor machine that we could swap the display with.
  2. The driver complains that the robot is driving funny. We inspect the swerve modules and find this: iCloud Photos - Apple iCloud Turns out our Velcro peeled up and the wires got caught in the module’s gearing. I guess it was so hungry for grease it would take anything.

Sorry for the weird photo links, CD’s still throwing a hissy fit and won’t let me upload attachments.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":56,"updated_at":"2024-08-07T06:58:33.317Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":550,"readers_count":549,"score":190.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":469589,"topic_slug":"whats-your-silliest-technical-issue","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://share.icloud.com/photos/02fQChDLbP2_vPVbt3SP55XSQ","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"iCloud Photos - Apple iCloud","clicks":71},{"url":"https://share.icloud.com/photos/07cEl7tn5Y8_B62ypinP3Wttg","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"iCloud Photos - Apple iCloud","clicks":57}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6238 alum (he/they)"},"post_url":"/t/whats-your-silliest-technical-issue/469589/9","custom_user_title":"6238 alum (he/they)","reactions":[{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413899,"name":"Yishai Levy","username":"levyishai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-07T10:56:18.970Z","cooked":"

Our robot was having CAN problems that don’t affect how it operates, and they appeared only when it is enabled.
Turns out this was caused by a KrakenX60 that shorts to frame from its axle only when the robot is enabled.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":56,"updated_at":"2024-08-07T11:04:23.851Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":513,"readers_count":512,"score":132.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":469589,"topic_slug":"whats-your-silliest-technical-issue","display_username":"Yishai Levy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57809,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator"},"post_url":"/t/whats-your-silliest-technical-issue/469589/10","custom_user_title":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413905,"name":"Nathan Shepherd","username":"NShep98","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nshep98/{size}/224800_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-07T12:25:44.563Z","cooked":"

One time at a Week 0, my team showed up having swapped PCMs. Our pneumatics kept firing very slowly or not at all. Turns out we just forgot to switch the jumper on the spare PCM from 12V to 24V.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":56,"updated_at":"2024-08-07T12:25:44.563Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":489,"readers_count":488,"score":147.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":469589,"topic_slug":"whats-your-silliest-technical-issue","display_username":"Nathan Shepherd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M"},"post_url":"/t/whats-your-silliest-technical-issue/469589/11","custom_user_title":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413929,"name":"Dan_Karol","username":"Dan_Karol","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan_karol/{size}/227378_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-07T14:54:44.170Z","cooked":"

In 2013, 131 CHAOS went to an offseason event. At that event, the robot wouldn’t launch the game piece correctly even though it had passed the systems check in the pit.

It turns out a black sock had ended up in the robot when it was transported to the event. The sock ended up in a launcher pathway that was only intended to interact with frisbees that had been picked up from the floor and we had never gotten that feature implemented but the software and sensor support was still there. The sock was blocking a vestigial beam-break sensor and the robot was trying to feed an imaginary frisbee that was in the lower launcher before feeding the real human-loaded frisbee in the upper launcher. We finally took a hit in just the right way where the sock hit the flywheel and was sent flying across the field, Problem solved.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":56,"updated_at":"2024-08-07T14:54:44.170Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":462,"readers_count":461,"score":287.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":469589,"topic_slug":"whats-your-silliest-technical-issue","display_username":"Dan_Karol","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7133,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"131 CHAOS"},"post_url":"/t/whats-your-silliest-technical-issue/469589/12","custom_user_title":"131 CHAOS","reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":12},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3413930,"name":"Sarah Withee","username":"geekygirlsarah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geekygirlsarah/{size}/172508_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-07T14:55:02.734Z","cooked":"

This reminds me of my college robotics team and we had a distance sensor that was occasionally just going haywire. We couldn’t really figure it out. Turns out they were mounted on conductive plastic (who knew?) and so the positive, negative, and signal wires were shorting each other out occasionally!

Oh no… silly mistakes indeed but my techy heart aches for those!

Maybe more of a design/practice flaw than a technical issue, but we were definitely discussing it with the field volunteers and FTAs.

Silly now. Wasn’t silly then. 2013 St. Joseph event. We had tried our climber out in the lab tons of times with a full side of a pyramid (but on a tile floor). Felt really confident. Get to a practice match and because of the field carpet and padding under it the pyramid sunk 1/4 inch down. This meant our initial bumper configuration would catch as we started our swing up to the first bar.

Cue several matches of no climb while we tried to get the bumpers moved as high as possible while being legal without snagging on the floor. In the end we got it and we’re still proud of being the first team to climb to level 3 at the event overall despite the delays.

Always practice like you play. Put the field props on carpet if they are supposed to be in the middle of the field. A tile floor is not the same. The friction and squishiness differences are significant and will make the robot act very differently.

At WVROX my team ran into an issue late into the night where our Drivetrain would stop working seemingly randomly. Immediately after getting off the field it would all work again. Over the course of a couple hours 2 very kind CSAs (one of which I’m pretty sure was @geekygirlsarah) helped up debug and replace some wires on our kraken motors that we thought could be the issue. Eventually we found out we had actually just not secured 2 can connectors together with our usual vex pwm clips. Immediately after adding those we stopped randomly breaking.

During the offseaoson before 2024 we were implementing discretization for our swerve drive. Trying to be fancy, I decided to update the loop time every loop rather than using a constant 22_ms. Unfortunately the way that I set up the variable meant the default value was 0, and it only updated when in teleop mode. Testing at home didn’t reveal a problem because we always enabled in teleop before enabling in auto. However when we arrived at our offseason competition it presented as a transient bug that would only occur at the field. Being in the pit we would run test mode, auto, etc… but always run teleop first. At the field, auto was the first thing running causing a divide by 0 in the speed sent to the wheels and a few holes burned in carpet.
